blocks.text: DEDICATION.
To the Girls and Boys of my Native Country.
I most respectfully dedicate King Bungaree's Pyalla, hoping it may interest them in the Folk-lore of that simple people, now fast expiring but who were once lords of this glorious land.
Mary A. Fitzgerald.

meta.author: G.W.L. Marshall-Hall
meta.title: A book of canticles

blocks.text: Persephone.
LIKE deathless silence that for evermore Sits lost in dreams among the lonely hills, She dwells, Persephone, in that dim world Where no sweet plaint of bird is ever heard,

Nor rustle of faint flowers shook by wind, Where footsteps have no fall, and sighs no sound, But everlasting hushfulness Doth strain the ear to listening agony, And night is not, nor day, but nothingness, Like that wan hour when light and dark are one. There death-pale poppies lie along the plain All sorrow-sere, and sick with loneliness, And lay their tired heads upon the sand Longing for easeful death that may not be. And on and on, and ever further on, And further yet, the flat insipid wilde Stretches its changeless weariness of waste As far as eye can follow, and beyond, And further still beyond— Till in pursuit baulked sight grows sameness-sick There is no motion there in anything, But nerveless death sleeps in the frozen air.

meta.author: G.W.L. Marshall-Hall
meta.title: A book of canticles

blocks.text: And She, immortal Mother, standeth there, Infinity fast shadowed in her eyes, Upon her arched brow, fateful, serene, The light of some huge pity hope-bereft. And awful Calm sits on her countenance, As on storm-furrowed seas the mirrored moon. Within her arms a wroughten chalice rests, And bleeding poppies hang upon its brim, And dying, their pale blood medicinal Sleep-giving, to its hollow sides bequeathe. From far, far vergeless void unto her feet, Like some tired, woe-begone, thin-trickling stream That scarce its weary length can drag along, A grievous throng of ghostly shadows flock Wearing a form like that which mortals have And wrapped in raiment such as mortals wear. One's forehead galls a crown of burning gold Whereat in vain his fevered fingers pluck, And one with hollow-gaping eyes up-turned His loose arms tosses wildly in the air Her cancered bosom yet another tears, On this one's front pain forges sweaty beads, And yon stares horribly through bursting balls, His woe-drawn features grinning in despair, And many with out-straightened arms, and hands Close-clenched, strive to hold in their agony. But most, abandoned to mute misery, Move listless on, nor ever from the ground Lift up their blank and sorrow-swollen eyes. They pass along, an everlasting train, Earth-born, earth-reft. And on each countenance Stern life hath written, " THIS AM I 1" ( 41)

meta.author: G.W.L. Marshall-Hall
meta.title: A book of canticles

blocks.text: And ever She stands there, and they press on, Nearing thus one by one her garments' hem With hollow eyes turned upwards, and wide arms, And parched throats gasping wild voiceless sobs :— "Weary are we of joy that ever wanes, And weary of wan woe. Weary of hope 'Wildered with waiting, weary of despair,— Weary of all that is, or was, or may be, But weariest of all of weariness." She notes them not, nor hears, but motionless, Far-gazing into faint futurities, Dippeth her finger in the fateful bowl, And as each furrowed face uplifteth so Layeth her tips upon the fevered mouth. E'en as a tiny babe, whose pouting lips Feel the maternal teats, slips into sleep. And from its little face fade suddenly All fretfulness, and pain, and hunger-want. So at the awful touch of godhead sinks Each death-doomed soul into forgetfulness. And everlasting slumber o'er him sways. But She, the deathless goddess, marks it not, But evermore her finger dipping thus And laying on new lips, looks into space. (42)

meta.author: W. Brooks
meta.title: Australian gossip and story / by the Globe Trotter

blocks.text: school at the time, in a back slum, for just such boys as Jo. We met on Sunday nights, and the bosses of the show were quakers ; real good people they were, too. The trouble with them was that they had theories about human nature, and they wouldn't lick a boy under any circumstances whatever. They hung on to Gospel truths until it came to " Spare the rod and spoil the child." Jo was the terror of their lives ! I proposed to take all the rag-tag to the public baths one morning a week and teach them how to swim, on condition that they behaved themselves, and took their Gospel physic nicely on Sunday nights. What a big school we soon had ; but poor, little untrained wretches, it was hard work for them to keep quiet at prayer times.

Soon after that Jo came to me with tears in his eyes, for we were good friends, in spite of occasional outbreaks, and told me that his little sister Mary had fallen down some steps and broken her arm ; would I come and see her. What a foul den they lived in. No wonder children grow up wicked ! It was the old story—a drunken father, a drunken mother, hunger, misery, and vice. Honour thy father and thy mother, eh ? I got little Mary off to an hospital, and when Jo went to see her she had on a red gown, and she sat in a clean white bed, such as the poor little mite had never seen in all her life before, and Jo was awed by the sight. He was as shy and timid as a young deer, and dared hardly go near Mary, and the pair of them just cried, poor little souls. Jo was tame after that. He learned to read, he went to school, and the last I saw of him he was a strapping, well-built young soldier rising rapidly in the service. When he bailed me up in the street one day I could hardly believe that the fine-looking military man was the red-headed little wretch who set the crabs adrift on the floor. But that's it, small boys, who have a lot of the devil in them, may be trained to make good men.

When I see how out' Australian small boys are left to them selves to grow up without training, without discipline, without learning how to obey, it makes me quake for the future of the race. My comfort is that I know some well-trained boys ; I know little fellows that it's a pleasure to be with, and I love children. But I never blame them for being bad; I blame their parents every time. That's a double-barrelled statement, too, and you can figure out what it means for yourselves if you feel that way. Of this one thing I'm perfectly certain—it's no good preaching that children should honour their parents. They'll do that every time if the parents are worthy of it. What we need to preach in Australia is that parents ought to do their duty by their children. If they did we wouldn't have so many larrikins and ne'er-do-wells in our streets. " Them's my sentiments, and I'm no child !"

meta.author: Greaves, Lilian Wooster, 1869-1956
meta.title: The two doves and other poems / by Lilian.

blocks.text: To My Pen.
Come hither, my pen, till I whisper to thee Of a message that someone has written to me, Of an ear that is listening in vain for thy song, Of a lip that complains thou art silent too long;

Of an eye that is watching in vain for thy word, Of a heart that is waiting by thee to be stirred. I am told thou art mighty, my modest wee pen, That the fruit of thy labour is welcomed by men. So I think, trusty friend, we must honestly try To take up our duty again—thou and I. Thou hast been my consoler through sorrow's dark night, When the angel of sleep from my bosom took flight; I've confided my soul's sweetest pleasures to thee ; Thou hast faithfully written love's message for me ; Thou hast blessed all my friends, and been silent to foes ; Thou hast shared all my joys, thou hast lightened my woes; Thou hast told to the weary where I have found rest; Thou hast taught the cold-hearted that loving is best; And thou knowest, my pen, that thy labour of love Is no more thine and mine than the blue sky above. In my right hand I hold thee, and tell thee my thought ; But I only can teach thee as I have been taught. Thou liest all still till I bid thee to move Even so am I silent till moved by God's love. A thousand sweet secrets are whispered to me, And I strive to interpret them rightly thro' thee ; And if the right lesson I happen to learn From the breath of a lily, the frond of a fern, And if thou can'st write it, and others are blest, How happy am I as I lay thee to rest. My pen, my dear confidante, comrade and friend, We must labour again, for not yet comes the end. Thou must tell to the wide world my message of love, While I tell to thee what I hear from above.

meta.author: Greaves, Lilian Wooster, 1869-1956
meta.title: The two doves and other poems / by Lilian.

blocks.text: Our Heroes.
We carve the names in marble, Of our beloved dead. Whose heart's blood for the honour Of our mother-land was shed.

And fame has writ the story U pon her page of glory, And points with radiant finger, tipped with flame, To every deathless name. We carve the names in marble, Of these, our living brave, Who fought with splendid valour ; An empire's hope to save. And glorious, conquering Britain Has in her annals written With mingled mother-love and martial pride— " My sons were by my side." Fame glorifies the soldiers, And England mourns the men ; But we—we mourn the loved ones We ne'er shall see again. They were our own heart's dearest— Our tribute is sincerest— Their names shall blossom thro' the coming years, Watered by our tears. A world looks on, admiring Our living brave returned ; But they are ours, these heroes— Our love hath o'er them yearned. As brothers, friends, and neighbours, They share our joys and labours. England may wreathe her brows with Austral flowers, But they will still be ours.

meta.author: Greaves, Lilian Wooster, 1869-1956
meta.title: The two doves and other poems / by Lilian.

blocks.text: The Fragments from the Feast.
When He brake the bread and fishes That the multitude might eat, As at eventide they lingered, Worshipful around His feet.

When the food beneath His blessing So increased and multiplied, That the thousands who received it All were fully satisfied. When He ordered His disciples All the fragments to retain ; And to gather into baskets Whatsoever might remain. Did He know that on the mountains, Weary, faint, and like to die : Groaning 'neath their heavy burden, Starving souls would wander by ? 1 fid He save for them the remnants Of that wondrous feast of old, For the wayward sheep who wandered From the Shepherd's blessed fold ? And, to-day, may I, repentant. Come, altho' the feast is o'er ?— Come and be a late partaker Of that still miraculous store. Lord, I come ! the crumbs and parings From the table Thou hast blessed, Are more precious to my spirit Than to be an earth king's guest.

meta.author: Greaves, Lilian Wooster, 1869-1956
meta.title: The two doves and other poems / by Lilian.

blocks.text: After a Bush Fire.
The valley swept a year ago by flame Is green again. The naked, blistered earth would cloak her shame, And hide her pain.

But we who knew each tender flower by name On hill or plain,— We know the scene will never be the same For us again. 'Tis but the stronger forms of life we see Grow gay and green. The sturdy fern, the deeply-rooted tree Re-robed have been. But the soft sweet things dear to you and me That grew between Are lost ; and this fair glen will never be As she hath been. To those afar, her banner of bright leaf The glen may wave ; And they may smile back in the proud belief That she is brave. But bur feet tread the ashes of her grief, Each step the grave Of some beloved flower or tender leaf That nought could save. . All del,' itch nursed by hidden springs, Sheltered by shade, Where thorny brambles, like armed warrior kings, Their safeguard made. S >ft in the earth's embrace these gentle things Were fondly laid, Until the fire-fiend, with his burning wings, Swept through the glade. Thus, O young heart, will anger, folly, sin, With tongue of flame, Destroy the precious things that long have been Thv dearest fame. The passing crowd may see no stain of sin. No .sign:'.of shame ; But thou, thyself, shalt h>nc;ly dwell within A leaf-screened frtpne.

meta.author: Brainerd, Eleanor Hoyt, 1868-1942
meta.title: The misdemeanors of Nancy / by Eleanor Hoyt ; illustrated by Penrhyn Stanlaws.

blocks.text: A DUMB-WAITER DRAMA

IT was while Nancy's family were in Florida that she and Priscilla shared lodgings. They went the dreary round of boarding houses. Each new hall bedroom was an additional sinker tied to the spirits of the two girls. Priscilla grew morbid and found it necessary to take a nerve tonic. Even Nancy, the irrepressible, lost her appetite and her gayety and became embittered. The sight of any of the many bachelor apartment houses scattered through the town moved her to impotent rage.

"My disposition is ruined," she confessed dismally; "when I pass one of those bach elor apartment places where unworthy men can get all the joys of paradise for $50 a month, I 'm like a mad dog who sees water. I positively froth at the mouth. I '11 marry the first bachelor who asks me, for the sake of getting even with him. As if petti coats were n't curse enough without adding hall bedrooms to woman's lot ! "

meta.author: Fitzgerald, Mary A
meta.title: King Bungaree's Pyalla and stories : illustrative of manners and customs that prevailed among Australian Aborigines

blocks.text: PREFACE.

In presenting to my young country people KING BUN GAREE'S PYALLA, I do so with some diffidence, lest, in my endeavour to render intelligible the legends told in imperfect English by the Black King, I may have weakened much of their original force and beauty.

The advent of civilization gave the Aborigines, who wore quick to imitate, occasion to modify the character of several of their original legends ; such, for instance, are those of the Beleck Beleck and the Dilbong.

The legends I have chosen, from the Pyalla, are only a few of the many I heard in childhood, but they may perhaps serve to give some idea of the style of stories existing among a people who, with their legends and romances, will soon have passed away for ever.
To the Pyalla I have added a few short stories illustra tive of some manners and customs of the aborigines, which have remained unchanged even down to our own time.
M. A. F.
SYDNEY, December 1, 1891.

meta.author: Fitzgerald, Mary A
meta.title: King Bungaree's Pyalla and stories : illustrative of manners and customs that prevailed among Australian Aborigines

blocks.text: INTRODUCTION.
A troop of merry children, Light hearted blithe and gay, Went rambling in the forest, On a bright and sunny day.
When a friend they love approaches, The children cease to sing. And soon are chatting kindly, With old Bungaree, the King.
"Pray tell to us, King Bungaree" They ask, with eager, words, " Why in this south'rn land abide, Such curious beasts and birds ?
Why swans, that to strange climes belong, Are robed in snowy white, While those in this fair land alone Wear feathers black as night.
Why laughs the odd Goburra, At morn and ev'ning hours. And how have the Tewinga Been taught to build their bowers ?
And tell us, good King Bungaree. About the Jlullangong, For truly this strange creature Has puzzled us too long.
And, dear good old King Bungaree, We know you'll tell us true, Why Weelah's ne'er sit hatching As other birds must do.

meta.author: Fitzgerald, Mary A
meta.title: King Bungaree's Pyalla and stories : illustrative of manners and customs that prevailed among Australian Aborigines

blocks.text: And tell us, wise old Bungaree, For mucli we wish to know, Why in so strange a fashion The Boleck's feathers grow.
And last of all good Bungaree, We'd like to hear you teli, How in the brush the Dilbong Have learnt to ring a bell."
" All that you ask dear children, I learnt in times long flown, When none but tribes of Koree, Called this golden land their own."
Then to the children clustering round The good King soft and low, Told of the curious birds and beasts, All that they wished to know.
And now one of that merry troop, That's scattered far away, Tells here the old King's stories On that bright and sunny day.

meta.author: Fitzgerald, Mary A
meta.title: King Bungaree's Pyalla and stories : illustrative of manners and customs that prevailed among Australian Aborigines

blocks.text: THE BLACK SWAN

meta.author: Fitzgerald, Mary A
meta.title: King Bungaree's Pyalla and stories : illustrative of manners and customs that prevailed among Australian Aborigines

blocks.text: THE MULLWEE.

THERE was in a broad calm lake in the north of our country an island, called by the Koree Wurta Wurta. When the flowering season came, the island seemed like a field of golden corn tipped with pink, blue and yellow blossoms. The passing breezes would catch the odours of the sweet flowers, and bear them away to the desert in the distant west where no flowerets bloomed. All around the margin of the lake grew tall rushes that looked like a guard of soldiers in bri ght green uniform, with white plumes on their heads. This calm lake and the lovely island were the resort of water birds such as the Kilkee, Krangi, Tha ralkoo, and others that came in the laying season, for there they knew their little ones would be safe.

One evening in the springtime, just as the sun was about to bid good night to the flowers, and when the rippling waters of the lake were chatting to them before they went to sleep, a rustling of wings was heard in the air, and a low sweet sound of music floated above Wurta Wurta, such as never before was heard there. The sleepy flowers opened their eyes and looking up saw two large birds, the fairest they had ever seen. Their feathers were far whiter than the dress of the noisy Curraways, that often flew over the island. The birds came nearer and nearer until they rested among the flowers, and then they ceased

meta.author: Fitzgerald, Mary A
meta.title: King Bungaree's Pyalla and stories : illustrative of manners and customs that prevailed among Australian Aborigines

blocks.text: to sing and began to preen their snow white feathers. The father bird said to his mate that he was glad they had found such a pleasant home after having come from over the sea. The flowers understood from the rest of their conversation that these birds were strangers that had come from some other land to ours ; and because of their grace and beauty the flowers gave them the name of " Mull wee."
In the next season the Mullwee gathered the dry dead rushes and reeds and made a cosey warm nest. There the mother bird laid some eggs, and hatched two white birdies.

When the little creatures swam on the lake, they looked just like tiny balls of Unify cotton floating on the bright waters, where they seemed to be as happy as the merry wavelets that laughed and danced around them. Once when these young birds were big and strong they swam for out into the lake, and saw for the first time the tall trees of the bush. This sight filled them with wonder and delight. They said to each other that they would go away and travel until they found a larger island than Wurta Wurta, and a more beautiful lake than their own. Their parents advised them not to venture into unknown places, whore much harm might befall them, but the young Mullwee only smiled, saying, they feared no dangers. Therefore when they had a chance, they commenced their wanderings. After having tra velled a long way they became tired and wearied, and being very thirsty they looked for a resting place where they could also get a drink. Presently they heard the sound of falling water, and searching about they found the entrance to a dell. This dell was surrounded by walls of rocks, except just in one place where

meta.author: Fitzgerald, Mary A
meta.title: King Bungaree's Pyalla and stories : illustrative of manners and customs that prevailed among Australian Aborigines

blocks.text: the summer breezes used to run in and out. There were lying all around ihe dell large pieces of rock and stone, that seemed as if some great giant had once stretched his strong hands down into the earth, and lifted up a huge handful of them and scatter ing them about, left this deep hollow in their stead. Here the Mullwee entered and saw a small lake or pool at one end of the dell. Into this pool fell a stream of bright water that came down the sides of the rocks from the land above. It sparkled and dashed and played with everything in its way, never keeping the same form, even for a moment, but twisted and whirled and danced like nothing in the world but itself; and all the while it sang a cheerful happy song.

This falling water never seemed to gee tired of its playful easy life, perhaps because it made everything in the dell green and glad. The only time it ever rested was in the middle of the hot summer days, when the breezes went to sleep for a little while, then it came down slowly in a simple little stream, looking so meek and mild, that one would scarcely know it but for its purling sound. When this joyous water fell into the lake in the dell, it ceased to sing, and lay there as quiet and still as if it had never danced and leaped and romped with the merry breezes on the rock sides. In the winter when great showers of rain fell, and the lake had too much water, it used to send a little stream hurrying away out of the dell, as fast as if it had been sent for.

All about the dell grew the loveliest of ferns, and many other plants that only thrive near water. When the Mullwee could see no danger they stepped very boldly into the lake and swam about in it and had a nice cool drink.

meta.author: Fitzgerald, Mary A
meta.title: King Bungaree's Pyalla and stories : illustrative of manners and customs that prevailed among Australian Aborigines

blocks.text: Now this dell and the land around it was the country of the Wambool, and the king of these birds had his nest in the branches of a stringy bark tree, overlooking the dell. The Wambool had chosen this place, because in the hot days small animals used to come there for food and shade, and many a good meal the (birds made of them.

The Woldja's kingdom was next to the Wambool, and the king of the Woldja lived in the tallest and biggest black butt tree that grew on the mountains. But although their coun try was very large the Woldja were not satisfied, but must come down into the dell whenever they saw a wingbah or meerri there, lor they said, that these were too big for the Wambool to catch, being fit prey for Woldja only.

It so happened that just as a great Woldja and his mate were flying home, without having caught even a rat for their family, they saw the two Mullwee on the lake in the dell. They had never before seen such large white birds, and they wondered much at the sight. After a few minutes talk between themselves they pounced down on the Mullwee, and catching them in their claws tried to carry them off. But the Mullwee struck at them with their strong wings, giving such hard blows, that the Woldja were forced to quit their hold ; but not without dragging out great tufts of the poor birds' feathers. Again the Woldja attacked, and again the Mullwee drove them off, but each time the cruel Woldja snatched away great bunches of the beautiful white feathers. This fierce battle continued for a long time Now the Mullwee were faint and tired, and then the Woldja seemed wearied, and about to give up the fight. But at last, the

meta.author: Fitzgerald, Mary A
meta.title: King Bungaree's Pyalla and stories : illustrative of manners and customs that prevailed among Australian Aborigines

blocks.text: Mullwee drove off the Woldja ; but not until the ground around, and the lake too were covered with snow white feathers and soft down, all torn from the brave Mullwee, that now lay beside the lake, bare and naked; and full of sorrow for having disobeyed their parents.

All this time the King: of the Wambool was seated in his nest in the stringy bark tree, watching the battle. But he nor his people, though no cowards, dare not interfere, for they had learnt long ago, that a Wambool was no match for a Woldja in fighting. But when he saw the Woldja flying away with angry cries, the King took pity on the strange birds, and calling all his people from far and near told them of the battle he had witnessed, and of the forlorn state of the birds in the dell below. " Let us help them." He cried ! "They have been stripped of their feathers by our dreadful enemies the Woldja. But still they must be brave birds, for never before have I seen the Woldja leave any bird or beast that they had once attacked. Let us help them. If you will all do as I do (and he plucked his beakful of black shining feathers from his breast), we will be able to offer the strangers a coat of feathers better than their own." All his people agreed to this proposal. And soon the whole flock, with their beakful of feathers, were ready to follow their King's orders. Then the King went into the dell, and speaking kindly to the Mullwee that were cold and trembling, offered to dress them in jet black feathers. The poor Mullwee gladly accepted this kind offer, but said they were sorry for losing their own white feathers, and related to the King of the Wambool, their whole history, also that of their parents. The King satisfied them, when he told them that

meta.author: Fitzgerald, Mary A
meta.title: King Bungaree's Pyalla and stories : illustrative of manners and customs that prevailed among Australian Aborigines

blocks.text: among his people, who came of a very ancient race, black was considered to be a sign of noble birth. And He added, " The men and women in this country are black, and they are the masters of all the birds and beasts." The King then made a sign to his people, who came flocking into the dell by thousands, and first of all he took his beakful of feathers, and carefully placed them in the pores left by the feathers that were torn away by the Woldja. Each in turn, came the great flock of Wambool, and followed the King's example, until at last the Mullwee were dressed in a perfect covering of shining black feathers, except beneath their wings, where their own white feathers were untouched. The Mullwee held a council, and agreed to leave the dell at once.
Before going away, however, they called upon the King of the Wambool to thank him for his kindness to them in their distress.

They told him that the white down feathers that were torn from them by the Woldja would not be lost, for they would all be turned into flowers, to make the Wambool's kingdom bright and gay. In the next season the Wambool were delighted to see in their country the loveliest flowers that ever grew. When the white man saw them he gave them the name of " Flannel Daisies."

Many years after, when a Hock of Mullwee, with their black little birds visited Wurta Wurta, they heard the story of the two strange birds that had come there once from over the sea, but had died of grief, when their children went away and returned no more.

meta.author: W. Brooks
meta.title: Australian gossip and story / by the Globe Trotter

blocks.text: OUR ILLUSTRATIONS. SYDNEY HARBOUR.

THE most wonderful city in the world is Sydney. It is the capital of New South Wales, and our colony has an area of 310,700 square miles, being a little over two-and-a-half times the size of Great Britain and Ireland. New South Wales is, roughly, 680 miles long and 760 miles wide. Our harbour has a water surface 15 square miles, and a shore line of 165 miles. Sydney and its suburbs occupy an area of 141 square miles, and the population numbers about 420,000 souls.
In 1788 the first settlement was made in Port Jackson, as our harbour is called, and the city of Sydney was founded January 26 of that year.

The Constitution Act was proclaimed on July 16th, 1855, and the lirst representative Parlieflnent was opened on May 22nd, 1856. Since that time the progress of the coiony has been enormous, and the vilva we give ffrewith will convey more clearly than any words how we have advanced, and give force to the words of William Charles Wentworth, written in the early years of the present century,—

"Should Britain cease to ride Despotic Empresi of old Ocean's tide, May this—thy last-born infant—then arise To glad thy .heart and greet thy parent eye ; And Australasia float, with flag unfurl'd, A new Brittania in another world."

In this volume there is an excellent photograph of Sydney Harbour, taken by Mr. Bayless, and the block has been lent to us by Messrs. Baker and Rouse, the well-known photo graphic supply dealers. Some of the photographs in this volume have been taken by Messrs. Kerry and Co., and we can say with considerable pride that Sydney can equal the best photographers in the world. We are not in any way behind the English or Americans in matters of photographic art, and the reproductions as seen in this book say more than chapters of words could, how the world goes with us in that respect. The Electric Photo Company has made nearly all the blocks, and they bear witness to what skill can do under the sunny skies of New South Wales.

meta.author: Atkinson, James
meta.title: On the expediency and necessity of encouraging distilling and brewing from grain in New South Wales

blocks.text: ON THE EXPEDIENCY AND NECESSITY OF ENCOURAGING DISTILLING AND BREWING FROM GRAIN IN NEW SOUTH WALES.

THE state of distress and privation under which the Colony has long laboured from a scarcity of bread-corn, has naturally led the more thinking part of our community to reflect upon the cause of the evil, and how to avert such distressing consequences in future. The partial failure of the two last harvests, is, no doubt, the proximate cause why grain has attained its present extravagantly high price. But all persons who are capable, from their oppor tunities of observation and information, of forming an opinion on the subject, are well convinced, that it is owing to the depressed and neglected state of agriculture, and that were our agricultural interests placed on a better footing and more encouraged, and were our farmers cer tain of obtaining a barely remunerating price for all the grain they can grow in plentiful years, a season would sel dom or never occur, however unpropitious, in which the Colony would not produce a sufficiency of bread corn for the support of its inhabitants; accordingly many persons have suggested different plans for the encouragement of agriculture. One proposes that a protecting duty should be levied on all foreign grain and flour; another, that stores and magazines should be erected in different parts of the interior, and that persons should establish them selves there as corn merchants and factors, in order to pur chase up the surplus grain in plentiful seasons; as if peo -

meta.author: Atkinson, James
meta.title: On the expediency and necessity of encouraging distilling and brewing from grain in New South Wales

blocks.text: ple would, from mere patriotic motives, expend their money in purchasing a commodity which they cannot be certain they should ever again be able to sell at a profit, while it is in a good state of preservation. The Govern ment, it is true, might do something of this kind; but even with all their vast means, it is much to be doubted whether they could, in this way, effectually remedy the evil complained of, as the quantity they could receive must necessarily have a limit, and it would be impossible for them to go on purchasing when two or three plentiful years occur successively, as is frequently the case. The quantity of grain that would then be accumulated in their magazines would act like a dead weight upon the markets, and depress the price of grain so low that it would not repay the cost of production. In my humble opinion it is not foreign competition that we need at all to dread, nor do I think it necessary that we should be dependent upon the bounty or patriotism of the Government or of individuals for the reward of our labours. The true point of policy seems to me to be—to devise such a plan as shall enable our farmers to grow any kind of grain suitable to our soil and climate, and to extend their cultivation so far, that it shall know no limit but the extent cf available capital and labour they can command ; and, at the same time, to enable them to consume any surplus they may ob tain upon their own farms, or to find a market for it in their own immediate neighbourhood.
It shall be my aim, in the following sheets, to point out a plan that will accomplish these desirable objects.

This plan has been Submitted to several of my friends, the greater part of whom have highly approved of it, and advised me to publish it; some others, for whose opinions I entertain the utmost deference, have entirely approved the system recommended, but thought the present time, when many peo le had not even bread to eat, was not a fit season to be talking of brewing and distilling from grain. For once, however, I am compelled to be under the necessity of differing from them. I cannot help think ing the present time, when the Public are still feeling the effects of scarcity, and when men's minds are fully im pressed with the necessity of something being done to

meta.author: Atkinson, James
meta.title: On the expediency and necessity of encouraging distilling and brewing from grain in New South Wales

blocks.text: protect and encourage the farmer, to he of all others, the most fit to agitate such a question especially when it is recollected that years of preparation must pass away be fore the plan can be carried into full effect; that land must be cleared and enclosed, working cattle broke in, and considerable buildings erected; that in short the whole disposable labour in the Colony must be put in motion, and the .government gangs, at present such an expense to the Crown, and such a nuisance to the people in their neighbourhood, must be drained of every man capable of performing agricultural labour. When it is duly considered that all this must be done to give effect to the proposed system, I am persuaded very few people will be found who will say that it is too soon to agitate the question of its propriety. The experience of past years should guide us as to what we are to expect in future. I have been nine years a landholder in this Colony, and seven years have cultivated my own farm. In this time, I have twice given wheat to my pigs, because I did not know what else to do with it; twice L have known wheat selling at fifteen shillings per bushel, and once at twenty shillings. What reason is there to expect the next seven years may not produce vicissitudes equally great, and equally dis tressing in their consequences.

Persons who have reflected upon the subject must have felt convinced that New South Wales is not fitted by nature to be a grain exporting country ; one great obstacle being its remoteness from any great market for grai i, but a still greater being the peculiar nature of the Country, destitute of navigable rivers of any extent, so that the fer tile country in the interior, much of which is well adapted for the growth of grain, is wholly cut off from any market beyond what the local demands of the district may require, which, of course, must be very limited, and any surplus obtained cannot profitably be got rid of.
It is necessary to make a few remarks on the impediments that at present obstruct the efforts of the farmer in the interior, before I proceed to detail the proposed plan.
The winters in all the more elevated parts or the coun try, especially to the westward of the Blue Mountains, are very severe, and the vegetation of the natural grasses

meta.author: Atkinson, James
meta.title: On the expediency and necessity of encouraging distilling and brewing from grain in New South Wales

blocks.text: entirely ceases for about four mouths in the year; it is, therefore, extremely desirable to cultivate such crops as will assist to feed live stock during that season. The soil and climate are well adapted for the growth of barley, peas, oats, rye, &c. the straw, chaff, and other refuse of which are little inferior to hay in their nutritive properties as cat tle fodder; and, if it were possible to consume the grain in such a way as to repay the cost of production, the far mer would derive considerable profit from the stock he would be able to keep on the straw, &c. I have no doubt that could the live stock, especially the sheep, be kept off the bush pasturage from the middle of June until the mid dle of October (I allude more particularly to Argyle), a given quantity of land would support double the number of animals it will under the present system. During the season alluded to, the sheep, especially if the season be dry, feed the grass down so close as to eat out the heart of the plant, and even the very roots; the pasture has no time to recruit and recover its strength, and in a few years be comes totally exhausted. Could, however, the stock be kept off in the winter and spring, until the feed had attained a good bite, it would hardly be possible to overstock it again that season. I have always been very desirous to extend my cultivation for the purpose alluded to, and also to lay down land permanently to grass, and to introduce a proper rotation of crops upon my farm and reduce my agricultu ral operations to some degree of system and regularity. I have plenty of fertile land, working cattle, agricultural implements, and other available means; and my early habitsand predilections have constantly prompted me rather to look to extended cultivation as the means of supporting my increasing live stock, than to depend upon the mere wild herbage for support. But I have constantly found all my hopes and efforts blasted, by the perfect impossibility of disposing or using my grain in such a way as to repay the cost of production. There is no effectual demand in this District tor any kind of grain excepting wheat, and the demand even for that is extremely fluctuating and pre carious. It is of no use to tell me there is a demand for barley for the breweries and distilleries in Sydney. It would be much to the same purpose to tell me there was a

meta.author: Atkinson, James
meta.title: On the expediency and necessity of encouraging distilling and brewing from grain in New South Wales

blocks.text: demand for it in Kamschatka or Nova Zembla, since all are equally out of my reach. It occupies a bullock team 12 days, and very often more, to perform a journey from this place to Sydney and back. The cost of conveying a bushel of wheat thither, even in the cheapest manner, is not less than five shillings, and of barley, not less than four shillings—both exceeding the cost of production upon the farm. It is evident that this circumstance must en tirely preclude the possibility of conveying grain thither, except in very scarce seasons. The settlers who were establishing themselves in the neighbourhood, and the graziers who were torming new stations in the country to the southward, have hitherto created a temporary and lo cal demand for wheat; but that is now at an end, or no longer to be depended upon; all those within a moderate distance of this place being row capable of supplying themselves, and even raising a surplus for disposal.

It has been objected that I have not taken into account the large distilleries near Sydney, as affording a market for grain ; and, also that it would be impossible to send spirits from this place to Sydney for sale.

To this I reply, that the distilleries near Sydney never have, nor ever can be of much use in encouraging agri culture ; at present I perceive a dollar per bushel is offered for rye, and if I lived within 10 or 15 miles of the dis tillery I should be glad to sell a considerable quantity of that grain I have now by me, at that price ; but the cost of conveying it to Sydney would exceed the price offered. The distillers, unless the duties were wholly taken off, cannot afford to give any other than a low price for grain. None is grown in the neighbourhood of Sydney, and any they do purchase must come to them burthened with a heavy charge for carriage. The grain that can ever be brought into Sydney by land carriage or coastwise by water From various parts of the Colony, will, I doubt not, find a better price at all times in the market than the distillers can afford to give; unless as I said before the duties were wholly taken off, or very much reduced. Had the enterpri sing individuals who have expended such large capitals in erecting the great distilleries near Sydney, but expended a fourth part of their outlay in erecting distilleries at Wind -

meta.author: Atkinson, James
meta.title: On the expediency and necessity of encouraging distilling and brewing from grain in New South Wales

blocks.text: $$Unclear$$ Penrith, or even Bathurst, or Wallis'Plains, I have no doubt they would have found their profits greater than they are likely to be in their present situation for many years to come.

A team of 5 good bullocks would draw at one load about 50 bushels ot'wheat, or 60 bushels of barley to Sydney, the former as above observed at the cost of 5 shillings, and the latter at 4 shillings per bushel. Seven hogsheads of spirits, including the casks would weigh about the same weight, and could therefore be carried from this place to Sydney at the costof about 7d. per gallon, which itwould very well afford. And supposing that a bushel of barley will produce one gallon and-a-half of overproof spirits, the produce of that bushel could be carried to market in the stiape of spirits for the cost of 10.id. which would be a saving of 3s. lfd. upon every bushel in the cost of car riage; and thus the entire produce of 280 bushels of grain could be drawn to market by one team, whereas nearly five times the same strength would be requisite to effect the same purpose in its raw state. This will I hope be a sufficient pioof that spirits maybe carried to market in Sydney, by land carriage, not only from this place, but from others double the distance; I need not observe what an important encouragement would thus be afforded to the agriculture of the interior. Barley might be grown, con verted into spirits, and carried to market in Sydney, by land carriage, from places more than 100 miles distant at less expense than it now costs to convey it thither in its raw state. Rye is a heavier grain than barley, and the cost of conveying it as grain would be still greater.

The frequent fluctuations in the market price of grain presents another very serious impediment to the progress of agriculture throughout the Colony generally. In scarce years like the present, the high prices tempt the farmers to makeevery effort to sow as much wheat as possible. Should the season prove favourable, a very great depression in the price is sure to follow. The cultivators, totheirgreat dis couragement, find the market price will not repay the cost of production, let alone the cost of carriage. Having no means of consuming it profitably at home, they are glad to part with it to traders and dealers at any price,

meta.author: Atkinson, James
meta.title: On the expediency and necessity of encouraging distilling and brewing from grain in New South Wales

blocks.text: and cultivate less next year; this, very probably, proves a bad season, and prices again rise. Thus alternate plenty and scarcity have characterised the Colonial markets from their first foundation; audit is impossible to say, with certainty, what is the cost of production or the average va lue of grain, since it not only varies so much from year to year, but also in different parts of the same year. Hence negligence and want of system, as farmers characterise the majority of our settlers, while their moral character suffers front the uncertainty of their incomes; being like gamesters, at one time rioting in the profusion of their unexpected gains, with the usual results of such success, depravity and intemperance: at other times sulfering all the ills of poverty and indigence.

The plan I am about to propose in this essay would, I have no doubt, have the effect of equalizing the markets, so as to keep the prices pretty steady; at least so far as to prevent those extreme fluctuations which have hitherto taken place. By creating a remunerating market for grain of all kinds, in even the most abundant seasons,cultivation would be so much extended thai, after the lapse of a few years, a season, as I have before stated, seldom or ever would occur in which the Colony would not produce suf ficient bread corn for its own consumption.

As I shall have frequent occasion to mention the neces sity of ensuring a remunerating price, I shall here state what I consider the cost of production upon the farm, without any expense of carriage. This, as I have before observed, is a point of great ditliculty, but from the best calculations I have been able to make, grounded upon the results of my own practice and experience, I should state the average cost of production as follows:—Wheat, 4s ; peas and barley, 3s. 6d ; and rye, 3s. per bushel.

It is now nearly eight years since distillation from grain under certain regulations has been allowed in New South Wales; yet this privilege, which was mostanxiously looked for and eagerly desired by the Colonists for many years, has failed to produce any real or permanent benefit to the agriculturists. The distilleries which have been erected have, I believe, been principally occupied in dis tilling from sugar, and the grain markets have still con -

meta.author: Walker, William
meta.title: An account of the great flood on the Hawkesbury of June, 1864, and the lesser flood of July following : with a statement of the steps taken for the relief of the sufferers ; originally written for, and published in, "The Sydney morning herald," now corrected and enlarged

blocks.text: CHAPTER I.
THE JUNE FLOOD.

Poor luckless creatures, wheresoe’er you are, That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm, How shall your houseless heads, and unfed sides, Your loop’d and window’d raggedness defend you From seasons such as these ? King Lear.
Sunday , June 12 th, 1864.

It is with feelings of the deepest melancholy, I have to record the par - ticulars of the highest Flood which has occurred at the Hawkesbury for many years. A more disastrous visitation of the kind has never been known. It commenced raining on Friday night, the 10th instant, and continued to pour incessantly for twenty-four hours, when the sky cleared, and the rain temporarily ceased. On Satur - day morning, the 11th, all the creeks were up, and the river was bank high. During the night of the same day, the waters continued to rise, and by daylight, on Sunday morning, a tremendous flood was in view. The torrent roared terrifically. Guns were heard fired off as signals of distress, from parties inundated in Cornwallis, and Wilberforce. The police boat was first got out. By five o’clock a.m. it was taken to the rescue of Mrs. Connolly, a poor widow, at the Peninsula; but the current was so strong, that the house could not be safely approached. Sometime afterwards, the boat was handed over to Mr. W. Alderson, who with a stouter and more determin ed crew made a second attempt, and succeeded in getting the poor woman off, after cutting a hole in the roof of her house, through which to get her out. It was not till eight or nine o’clock however, that all the boats at command could be manned and got into use. They had their work to do, and were employed the whole forenoon, in bringing off the unfortunate flooded families from their houses. Many of the poor people had to be taken off the lofts and roofs of their dwellings ; and it was pitiful to see the women and children, drenched with wet, who, in numerous instances, had to be rescued; some were found standing up to their waists in water. In the town of Windsor, the water came this morning up within a foot of the Barrack Gate, in Bridge-street; the Fitzroy Bridge itself was wholly under water. The Toll-house and adjoining buildings, with the Old Windsor Hotel, were entirely flooded ; whilst Mr. Me Donnell’s public house, the property of Mr. W. Johnston, and several cottages higher up, were half filled with water. Hear the

meta.author: Walker, William
meta.title: An account of the great flood on the Hawkesbury of June, 1864, and the lesser flood of July following : with a statement of the steps taken for the relief of the sufferers ; originally written for, and published in, "The Sydney morning herald," now corrected and enlarged

blocks.text: ferry, Dr. Day’s cellar was three feet under water, and Cadell’s brewery, and Beddek’s cottages along the hanks of the river, were half-way flooded. The waters came into George-street, byway of Caddell’s paddock and lagoon ; and they went down Maequarie - street, near Mr. Burke’s cottages, at the one end, and by Marsden's paddock at the other. The old brewery, Cornwallis, was flooded half-way up, and the whole of Fairfield Flats, up to within a foot or so of Atkinson’s viaduct, on the railway. Along South Creek, the waters came nearly level w r ith the Taylors’ viaduct, and portion of the railway embankments, at Cunneen’s, have sunken, and been partially carried awav. The water came half-way up McGrath’s Hill, covering several of the cottages near the foot. There is a perfect sea in front of the Windsor Terrace. The whole of Corn - wallis, Eichmond and Clarendon Bottoms, Freeman’s-reach, Wilber - force, and Pitt Town Bottoms, are under water. Mr. E. Eobinson’s house, which stands comparatively high, and never was known to be flooded before, has four feet of water in it. One of the Penrith Punts was seen early this morning floating above Cornwallis, and it was supposed three men were in it.—lt was afterwards secured. The Windsor punt was fastened safely to a large tree, near the ferry, which has often been used for a similar purpose, having survived many floods which have taken place around it. The loss of property, occasioned by this visitation, must be im - mense. A large quantity of maize, standing and stored, has been destroyed, and stacks of hay have been carried away in abundance. The settlers had been taken so much unawares, that they had neglected in many instances to drive their stock in proper time to the high lands. Numerous cattle, horses, and pigs have conse - quently been drowned. Fowls, pumpkins, and other farming pro - duce might be seen floating irrecoverably away down the river, in numbers and quantities considerable. A few only of the stacks have been saved, by tying them with ropes. Some industrious persons caught great numbers of fowls. Successful efforts have also been made to save horses, but the instances are very few. Furniture and household effects have been hopelessly washed away. The only person I know, who managed, by means of his own boat, to save part of his domestic goods, was Mr. His. Cunningham. It was pleasing to notice, how anxious every one that could, was to help the unfor - tunates. The possessors of the few boats available, lent willing assistance, in every w r ay possible. The telegraph posts and wires are under water, between Windsor and Magrath’s Hill; also between Windsor and Eiehmond, and all communication in that way, or by means of the coach to Blacktown, with Sydney has been stopped. It is believed that some of the wires have been broken. It is calculated that the waters have risen upwards of forty feet —and are higher than the heavy flood of 1857, when the Dunbar was wrecked at the Sydney Heads. The old hands about, all concur in saying that so high a flood lias not been known these forty years. 1 p.m. I regret to say, it has recommenced raining slightly, and the waters still continue slowly to rise. The greatest excitement prevails in the town, and the places of worship are all but deserted,

meta.author: Walker, William
meta.title: An account of the great flood on the Hawkesbury of June, 1864, and the lesser flood of July following : with a statement of the steps taken for the relief of the sufferers ; originally written for, and published in, "The Sydney morning herald," now corrected and enlarged

blocks.text: some of them quite closed. The School of Arts, and other public buildings have been then opened for the shelter of the poor flooded - out people, who are now crowding in town. Their sad countenances too truly depict the misery they are enduring. There is no doubt their distress will be great; and this visitation will be severely felt for many a long day. One gratifying fact amongst the surrounding gloom is that, no life has been lost so far as can be known, though I should not be at all surprised at hearing of some such casualty.
Monday , 13^.

Hoon.—The waters rose several feet during the night, and are now fifty feet above the usual level of the river. About eleven this morning, they broke across George-street, and came up to the verandah of Mr. Collison’s house. Prom Macquarie-street by Suf - folk-street, the flood has nearly reached to George-street, and a “ meeting of the waters” has almost taken place here, which, if consummated, would have placed the north-eastern end of Windsor on an island, and have cut it off from the south-western side. There is a vast expanse of water in view over Mr. Bidge’s Paddock towards Magrath’s Hill. Hr. Hay’s houses in Macquarie-street, occupied by Mr. Stonier and Mrs. Sharp, have the water in their ground-floors, the back premises being flooded half-way up. Mr. Horset’s kitchen and yard are also inundated. Mr. Horset, an old hand, says —so high a flood has not taken place since the one of 1819, which he witnessed. There are several feet of water now over the railway line, and the arches of the South Creek viaduct can only be seen, and are covered half-way up. In Bridge-street, the waters have come past the corner of Macquarie-street, to Mr. McQuade’s property, the old blacksmith’s shop. The roof of the old Windsor hotel, McHonnell’s public house, and some other cottages, have fallen in—parts of the walls have also given way, and the furniture and goods are being washed up Bridge-street, in large quantities. Mr. John Tebbutt’s residence, “ Peninsula House,” no longer holds its name. It stands now on an island, a small green knoll, as the water is within a few feet of the dwelling, The kitchen and cellars of Hr, Hay’s house, near the ferry, are completely filled, and the whole of the yard and stables are under water. Cadell’s brewery is flooded more than half-way up, and the water has come within a few yards of Mrs. Cadell’s house, Cockenzie Bank. The court-house, goal, and Mr. Edgerton’s residence, are now on a peninsula, there being only a narrow track of land in the police paddock, to connect them with the town. The garden of Claremont Cottage is in the lower parts quite submerged and the water not far from the Eev. Mr. Moore’s residence. Ivot an atom is to be seen of the viaduct of Eairfield, and it is believed the earthworks have partially been washed away. From a view through a glass, we can perceive the water nearly up to Mr. J. McHonald’s house, at Pitt-town, and not far off the first inn at McGrath’s Hill. Very little more would cause it to break over into the Bichmond Hill Common.
The sufferings of some of the settlers arc most severe—many of them have lost their all—the hard earnings of a life. They have

meta.author: Bradley, Charles
meta.title: The Belgrave case : a romance of Melbourne life / by Charles Bradley.

blocks.text: THE BELGRAVE CASE.
CHAPTER I. A TOORAK MYSTERY.

A bedroom in the Grand Hotel, dimly discerned by the feeble rays of a solitary candle that is burning 1 sluggishly on the dressing table. The room is half-filled with tobacco smoke, having the appearance, through the pale light, of being wrapt in fog. The hands of a small American timepiece, hanging by the bedside, point to a few minutes to four. It is early morning. Now a deathlike stillness, save for the incessant tick, tick of the timepiece, which only intensifies the silence. Now, distant and low rumblings of thunder may be heard, dying away like the voices of breakers on a receding shore, fainter and fainter. They are the final echoes of one of the heaviest thunderstorms remembered in Melbourne for many years. The lightning is still playing feebly around the horizon, but the sullen-looking candle flame is now sufficient to disguise the vagaries of the electric spark that has been darting and writhing in sinuous lines hither and thither for several hours, and inscribing startling hiero - glyphics upon the walls of the chamber. “What a terrible night it has been.” There is someone seated at the dressing table. It is a man, leaning forward and resting his head upon his hands. He is the only occupant, and the sentence just quoted he spoke in a low tone to himself. A large note-book or diary is open before him, the page uppermost being closely filled with writing, and not yet dry. At his elbow is a big official B

meta.author: Bradley, Charles
meta.title: The Belgrave case : a romance of Melbourne life / by Charles Bradley.

blocks.text: is my next door neighbour. He is such fine company. If I thought it was he I would bowl him out, for I shant sleep much to-night. I don’t think I had better risk it, or if there was a hitch I might bring the whole hotel down upon me, thinking I was a burglar, or something of the sort.” He turns to the open book on the dressing-table. “There, Mrs. Diary, I have entered all I know of the Toorak affair. Something like a novelist would describe it, eh ? It will be a famous case, mark my words, Mrs. Diary. I must have a whiff for a few minutes to freshen me before I read you through, Mrs Diary. Where’s my Turk’s head.” A scramble amongst a heterogenous gathering of papers, and the usual bachelor’s bric-a-brac is the means of drag - ging to the surface, by instalments, a Nubian species of pipe. After replenishing the bowl with a very mealy and sabled hued mixture, ho bonds over the candle to get a light. In the interesting occupation of charging his pipe, Abagal had not noticed that the candle was spurting and leaping spasmodically, it being almost burnt down, and at the moment he applied for the light it took a final leap into seeming eternity. It was a very big D that escaped the benighted detective. Being almost a stranger to tho place, he was unaware that the lighting facilities were available for any hour of the night; he had becomo accustomed, on board ship during the voyage from Eng - land, to the lights in the cabins being extinguished at eleven; so he had laid in a store of candles. The packet, by-and-bye, he succeeded in extricating from a portman - teau. He fixed up two of the candles, and gained a more satisfactory illumination than before; then he lighted his pipe, and a look of complacency settled upon his features. Diming this performance he had not noticed that the room door was opened, it was done so noiselessly; nor did he observe until he had settled back again into his chair that there was another in the room. He was amusing himself by blowing wreathes of tobacco smoke from his pipe, and watching their fantastic evolutions in tbe air, when his eyes met those of another, which so startled him that the pipe dropped from his mouth upon the open di/iry. “Heavens defend us, Learelle! How the deuce ” he exclaimed.

meta.author: Bradley, Charles
meta.title: The Belgrave case : a romance of Melbourne life / by Charles Bradley.

blocks.text: “ Yes, that is the name of the house.” “ Strange that he should know nothing,” he said to himself. Then, as if mechanically, he took from the offi - cial envelope that had been posted to him from Scotland Yard, a document, and in a listless manner he perused it. He asked himself why he had done this, like one toys with any trifle when in an abstracted mood, he surmised. The document he glanced at contained a few further particulars for the arrest of one Maurice Blackmore, wanted by the London authorities for fraud. The news of the famous Blackmore frauds was becoming an important topic in Melbourne, since it had been reported that the man had got away from England, and it was current that he had landed somewhere in Australia. “The latest description contradicts the first,” he continued to himself. The only peculiarity they have found out is the colour of his eyes — almost red they say.” At this lie laughed. “ Like yours, my friend,” he thought, gazing across at Learello, who seemed in a reflective mood at this moment. “ Like a score of others I have met.” In replacing the document, a small folded piece of paper dropped from the envelope. Abagal did not notice from whence it had fallen ; he thought as he stooped down to pick it up, he might have brushed it off the table in reaching over; nor did he guess it was of any importance. He started on opening it. It was a photograph, carte de visite size, on proof paper, unmounted. From the manner in which it was folded, it might be surmised that it had been pushed in the envelope after the document was sealed up, and had remained stuck where it had been placed until this instant. “Ha! Here is a photograph of you, Learolle,” said Abagal. “ Photograph of me. Nonsense. It is years since I had one taken,” replied Learelle, awaking from a brown study. “It is very like you, only about twenty years younger, my friend.” “ Let me see it.” Abagal handed the photo to him. He seemed to betray a little excitement on looking at it, and then, with an ejaculation that expressed disgust, he tore it up in very small pieces and crossed to the window.

meta.author: Bradley, Charles
meta.title: The Belgrave case : a romance of Melbourne life / by Charles Bradley.

blocks.text: guided, was the instinct that, web-like, immersod those whom for his own profit ho desired to fraternise with. Abagal and Learelle had met on board ship during the ■voyage out from England, and had by this time become sworn and fast friends. Without doubt, Abagal had every belief in the integrity and brilliancy of his acquaintance, and had confided in him regarding most matters; invari - ably seeking Learelle’s advice. The light falling fully upon the face of Hearne Abagal will allow of a vague delineation of his mind and features. He was merely a plain sort of fellow, whom one could not help remarking had a plentiful force of character, of rather dark complexion and greyish eyes. He had a thin moustache, which could not possibly flourish from the innocent toying it got. Every line of his face betokened intelligence, sluggish certainly, and the perceptive faculties overhung the eyes with marked development. Stay ! A remark his friend, Learelle, has made, changed the features of the face as by a flash. Hogged determination ; a will of iron ; an unrelenting hatred of that which dared betray his confidence; a subtlety so blended with candour, that none but a skilled physiognomist could comprehend correctly. Withal, this man is of the stuff that success is made of ; being not particularly brilliant, but constant, and with one motto ever before him, perseverando. He was squarely built, of medium figure, and, as he crossed the room, it might be noticed how firm was his step. “ Don’t keep me mystified any longer, Hearne, old boy. Take another weed, and tell me of the great event that has so disturbed you. Ah! I think I guess now. You have found a clue to Maurice Blackmore.” “No.” “Then it is the thing reported in to-night’s papers,” said Learelle. “I don’t know anything of importance that has been reported in the papers to-night,” answered Hearne. “ Come, don’t let me call you an ass. You don’t know of the escape of a man named Leroux, from Pentridge ?” “What!” Hearne Abagal started. “I read the papers through and saw nothing of it.” “It was in the last editions. The reporters didn’t get a hint of the affair until late. The authorities thought

meta.author: Bradley, Charles
meta.title: The Belgrave case : a romance of Melbourne life / by Charles Bradley.

blocks.text: The mail steamer reached Williamstown this morning, and in company with one of the Melbourne detectives I boarded her. No success. Journeyed right away from Williamstown, at nine, to Pentridge. About eleven had an interview with the Governor of the Gaol, and after - wards was taken by one of the warders to examine a man named Henri Leroux, who was formerly an associate of Maurice Blackmore.” “That would be just before he escaped,” interposed Learelle. Hearne nodded, and proceeded to read his diary.* “ Could get no information from the Frenchman. I found him a very surly sort of brute. Had a look round Pentridge—thought the system good. I found the Mel - bourne detectives very smart, and think the service here equal in most respects to that of Scotland Yard, savo that the disguises may not be as clever. They appear to bo too well-known to the general public to havo really fair opportunities.” “ I am getting tired of this,” again interrupted Learelle. “The style is not only amateurish, but there is nothing to interest one.” “There’s something behind you that may interest you more,” replied Abagal petulantly. “Robertson’s Whisky, take a night-cap, it may give you more zest for the excito - ment I have on the road. I’ll cut the dialogue and come to the ’Osses !” He proceeded with the reading. “ Interviewed the Chief of Police in the afternoon. Got a wire from Sydney that someone well acquainted with Blackmore was leaving by to-day’s mail, and would give me every assistance I might require for his identification.” Learelle was in the act of draining his glass, but this last sentence startled him somewhat. After, in a quiet tone, he asked— “ Hid the wire give the name of the man able to recog - nise Blackmore ?” “No. The fellow will call upon me here to-morrow at noon.” Again he proceeded with the diary. “ Returned home very tired in the evening about seven o’clock. My detective friend persuaded me to go to the
•There must be some mistake here. Leroux is reported to have escaped very early in the day. Perhaps it was the morning before when Abagal saw him.—C.B.

blocks.text: CHAPTER II. THE SHADOW ON THE VERANDAH.
may say it was, but I moan to solve the mystery, and—” “ And I will help you.”

It may "be of greater interest to gain an insight into the circumstances that led up to the tragedy related in the previous chapter by the English detective. An expose of the events of the previous five or six hours, being about an hour before Haddon despatched the man with the note for Abagal, will be of use in laying bare the motives which may have existed whereby the deatli of Powe Haddon was brought about. Was it suicide or murder ? If the latter, whom would his death profit most? Rowe Haddon and George Preston, M.L.C., were seated upon the lawn of Chantilly, Toorak. It would be about ten o’clock in the evening. The two men had been silent some little time, when Haddon at length spoke. “I don’t think it will be long before the storm bursts upon us, Preston,” he said. “I dare say within an hour,” replied his companion. He appeared to be watching with interest the increasing lightning that pierced the folds of heavy clouds that for hours past had been coming over from the north. “It has been very close and sultry for the last two days, now. What a relief when the storm does burst.” “ I suppose we may expect this sort of tiling, as we are close upon November now; yet what an irrascible climate we have in these parts. I have experienced every season of the year in one day here in Melbourne,” said Haddon. “Withal the place never seems to lose its attractiveness. We old settlers think there is only one City in the World, and we call it Melbourne.” “ Anyhow, I find Melbourne more trying than I found London.” “The excitement, in a great measure, will account for that,” answered Preston. “ London is brimful of every -

meta.author: Bradley, Charles
meta.title: The Belgrave case : a romance of Melbourne life / by Charles Bradley.

blocks.text: fever of gambling is very contagious. Wherever it is honest, it is healthful, and tends to sturdy and prosperous development. To a country, young and untilled, as this, it is needful, and cannot fail to return four-fold wherever there is reciprocity of purpose, where the idea is profit only, and not plunder. I wont believe anything so bad of you Eowe. No friend of mine could bo knave enough to be the originator of such a series of frauds.” “You are very severe, Preston. Why, two-thirds of the business of the exchanges in the colonies came from the floating of the petty mining schemes.” “ And two-thirds of the ruin.” “ There were profits made ” “ By the promoters.” Preston laughed a cynical laugh in reply ; and the two occupied themselves beating back the mosquitos—as Preston has termed it, smoking ferociously. The Honorable George Preston’s home was a modern villa, cosily embowered in tall dark firs, and garlanded on every side by palms, willows and variegated foliage of the cactus species. It was a charming chatelet, standing in somewhat extensive grounds that were adorned with summer houses, and chastely constructed conservatories, containing the choicest of choice shrubs and flowers. Toorak, of all Melbourne suburbs, is most famous for its handsome residences, and George Preston’s mansion in its picturesque position, crowning a natural eminence, was much coveted by surrounding residents, for its locality and excellence of convenience and design. Broad marble steps led up to its entrances, and the large hall, where the guests were being deposited, was artistically panelled and adorned with French crayon sketches, the choice of George Preston’s young wife, whose refinement was apparent throughout the establishment; whether in the collections of bric-a-brac and designs to please the eye, or the arrangements to minister to the comforts of all who visited the hospitable demesne, called by its owner, Chantilly. It was impossible to distinguish the design of the grounds, save at each flash of lightning, which sometimes had a wierd effect when it brightly glinted through the dark firs and shed a strange colouring over the richly shaded parterres.

meta.author: Bradley, Charles
meta.title: The Belgrave case : a romance of Melbourne life / by Charles Bradley.

blocks.text: “It is easy to divine from the present crisis. A revolution, the city in ashes, and, phoenix-like, rising from the ruins a greater and more substantial organization. Don’t you think that this place is eventually destined to become the chief city of the great southern empire, that in the transition of things cannot fail to be. Europe appears to be utilizing this country as the field of the struggles of capital and labour. Don’t you think that it is ? ” “Too heavy!” interrupted Preston; “don’t you think so?” in a good-natured manner. “The air is so very oppressive, and my brain is too fatigued to follow you. I have promised to dive into your articles on Federation. I’ll make my words good, if it is possible to get a copy. I have tried several times, but the booksellers tell me they have sold out.” “ I will bring you a copy to-morrow, if I am alive.” He appeared to shudder as he spoke the last words. Did some ominous recollection enter his mind ? If I am alive. “By jove, Preston, I positively shivered, although it is so warm. Someone walking over my grave, eh ?” Then they relapsed into silence. To-day, George Preston’s daughter, Gladys, had attained her majority. A magnificent gathering of many of Melbourne’s elite crowded the specially decorated rooms of Chantilly in celebration of the great natal event. It was to-day that George Preston thought w'ould be one of the happiest of his life, but a strange feeling of sadness had crept over him, he could not account for it, unless it was the vague idea that his friend, with whom he now sat, had brought him ill tidings. lie suspected something when he asked him to adjourn to a quieter part. This portion of the lawn was the only unoccupied spot about Chantilly. It was too much in the open for a lover’s retreat, and appeared too dull for others; so the two were uninterrupted for some time. What an honest open face was George Preston’s ; it had been bronzed by many a fierce sun under the Southern Cross. Generally very cheery, his voice betrayed a rather sad ring in it to-night. To-night, of all nights, when he should have been light-hearted, Perhaps

meta.author: Bradley, Charles
meta.title: The Belgrave case : a romance of Melbourne life / by Charles Bradley.

blocks.text: of liis friend. Haddon was not generally admired, and had never been married. As in all lives such as his there was a love secret locked away that might have been the slow poison of his career. It was his seeming cunning nature that found few friends, and the cause of his close association with George Preston was owing to a partnership that had existed between them in the earlier days, when conjointly they had invested their limited amounts in stock for a selection, and worked together. Those were the golden days for George Preston. Haddon had always prospered financially. In fact it was only when the partnership was destroyed that Preston began to make losses, whilst Haddon continued in his successful specula - tions, and was now voted an enormously wealthy fellow. The darker side of his character was thus gilded over, and few troubled to probe beneath the surface whilst his financial position was so unassailable. So he was accepted by society from the fact that society is not at all times exempt from pecuniary privations, and it might be necessary to make a call at some inopportune hour of the day. Not that Rowe Haddon was ever known to relieve a necessity, nor that he was ever asked. Still, he possessed influence. Haddon broke the silence that for some few minutes had been observed between the two. “So this is the night of the celebration of your daughter’s comingof age. Lucky girl. Ah !” he sighed. He was going to say more—that she reminded him of one whom he once hoped to make his wife, but Preston’s rejoinder prevented him. “Yes, to-morrow she will be mistress of fifty thousand pounds.” “Lucky girl,” repeated Haddon. “How like her mother.” Again a sigh broke from him. “ The money she will get was given to me by her mother.” “ I know, I know. It was left to her some time after your wedding. It was from the sale of some property in the old country, adjacent to my father’s home in Devon.” “I vowed to my wife that I would make good every penny of the money I had received from her. It was on her death-bed I promised her it should be settled entirely
