blocks.text: “I shall take it as a privilege, old friend,” answered Haddon. Then, after a moment’s reflection, he continued, “It is strange, at least it appears to me so, that Ledger did’nt mention any other matter to you, either by letter or by a verbal message through this Mr. Learelle.” “I have no idea what you are referring to. Is it something that has happened to Ledger?”—taking the cue from Haddon’s answer, that it was a matter of serious account. “ What! Not heard of the famous Blackmore frauds ?” “ What have they to do with Ledger ? ” Preston asked. “Don’t you read the English papers?” “ They have gone up to my station in New South Wales lately, and, being so busy, I have not troubled about having them re-addressed. I seldom go to the Club now, so lam really in ignorance. Oh, yes, I saw something in the London letter of the Argus ” A bright flash of lightning, quickly followed by a heavy thunder peal, prevented the finish of the last sentence being heard. At the same moment a female form, in a handsome evening dress of delicate tint, appeared at one of the Frencli casements. The light being behind, only the outline of the form was discernable. The seeming shadow advanced upon the verandah. It was, by appearances, the figure of a graceful and beautifully formed woman. She stood looking around, near the trellis work, resting her hand amongst the clinging verdure of the passion flower.

meta.author: Victor J. Daley.
meta.title: At dawn and dusk

blocks.text: THE RAJAH'S SAPPHIRES

In my garden, 0 Beloved ! Many pleasant trees are growing, Peach, and apricot, and apple, Myrtle, lilac, and laburnum. Fair are they, but midst them lonely, Like an exiled Eastern Princess In a strange land far from kindred, Stands a lonely fair Pomegranate. Dreaming of its native Orient Always is the fair Pomegranate, And beneath it I lie dreaming Of thine eyes and thee, Beloved ! Overhead its red globes, gleaming Like red moons, old tales recall of

meta.author: Victor J. Daley.
meta.title: At dawn and dusk

blocks.text: Eastern moons and songs of Hafiz— Nightingales, and wine, and roses. And at times it seems a mystic Tree Circean, whose red fruit is Broken hearts of old-time lovers, Thus their secrets sad revealing. And within each red sun-cloven Glossy globe, like little rosy Hearts within a great heart glowing, Glow translucent seeds of crimson. Like the fruit of the Pomegranate Full of little hearts my heart is, And the little hearts so glowing They are thoughts of thee, Beloved ! Haply these at times are woven In with dreams of the Pomegranate ; Thus, perchance, I dreamt the wondrous Dream within a dream here written.

meta.author: Victor J. Daley.
meta.title: At dawn and dusk

blocks.text: In his palace-hall, methought, I Saw a splendid Indian Rajah; Fame and Fortune were his vassals, But his heart was sad within him. Round him stood his chiefs and captains. u Great art thou,” they cried, “ 0 Rajah ! And thy hand is strong in battle.” But he smiled not at their speeches. Silently through his Zenana Passed he, glanced with cold and careless Eyes at women, fair as liouris Seen in visions bred of hasheesh. Like to dawn, and noon, and starry Night—like all the moods of passion— Were they, rose-and-white Circassians, Amber Hindoos, dark-eyed Persians. Dancing girls with golden armlets, Golden rings around their ankles — Making music clear, melodious As the plash of crystal fountains

meta.author: Victor J. Daley.
meta.title: At dawn and dusk

blocks.text: Heard in still, hot nights of summer — Danced the Lovers’ Dance before him; But he heeded not their dancing, For his heart was sad within him. Thence unto his treasure-chamber Strode he —there to gaze on gems that Rajahs dead had won and hoarded; Tragic-storied, splendid jewels— Flashing diamonds, like fallen Stars, for whose bright evil beauty Blood in old days had been spilt that Should have made them burn like rubies; Emeralds greener than Spring’s garments, Pearls like unto tears of Peris Weeping by the gates of Eden; Opals with their fateful lustre. Long on these, and countless other Many-coloured gems, the Rajah Gazed, but found no more delight in Their sun-flashing brilliant beauty.

meta.author: Victor J. Daley.
meta.title: At dawn and dusk

blocks.text: He had dreamt a dream enchanting Of twin-sapphires, blue as Heaven, And his heart was filled with hunger And with yearning to possess them. Therefore unto his Yizier he Told his dream, and gave command that He should seek the wide world over, Till he found the wondrous sapphires. Doth that sad Yizier still wander O’er the earth the sapphires seeking ? Sooth, I know not —but I know that He will never find them, never. For they were no cold, bright sapphires That the Rajah in his dream saw. . . . Waking from my dream I knew that They were thy blue eyes, Beloved !

meta.author: O'Reilly, Dowell, 1865-1923
meta.title: Australian poems / by D.

blocks.text: In Memoriam. CHARLES BADHAM, D.D

Hu loved the pictures that long-vanished souls . Left of their glory, traced in living words. ( He loved their beauty that reflected, shone With burning light from his pure soul —that shone Through his clear crystal soul of sympathy ; Their classic glory mingling with his love.
He loved their beauty, yet his sympathy Like sunshine brightened all. Its crystal sides, Scattered his love-rays o’er mankind. Their light Lit the dark home, and banished sorrow’s night.

Speak of freed souls with awe. From Spirit world They float to hover o’er life’s grave, as life Stands mournfully o’er death. Their gentle hands Pluck weeds from where loved spirits, still entombed, Dream of united love in spirit-land.
In life he left the pictures of those souls Whose spirit fellowship once more he leaves, To breathe deep love o’er loved ones, and mankind.

meta.author: O'Reilly, Dowell, 1865-1923
meta.title: Australian poems / by D.

blocks.text: The brooklet sobs upon the shore,
“ Peace nevermore,” “ Peace nevermere Childhood glides through the gloomy door Of manhood’s sorrow—evermore.
Brook born of cloud and mountain, thy sad life Is man’s. First babbling childhood’s tiny steps— The laughing boy’s bright song —-hushed, as he sees In trembling glory, flashing far beneath,
Love’s rainbows lovely fall, the life-stream thence, Passion-polluted, steals through darkening gloom, O’er the black confines of eternity.
Storm spirits sweeping by. “ Loved spirit, come,” They call—“ Break thy frail prison bars, with us Drift o’er the billows of eternity,
Seeking the still and happy spirit land.”
Gone, ere some mocking echo whispered “ Come.

Break, thou small wave of human ocean, break On death’s dark shore, sob voices from the deep. A star from dai'kness into darkness shoots Across black night—Fly, reckless spirit, fly From thy dark thoughts to dark eternity.
Bright Southern Cross, emblem of peace, thy beams Hallowed my birth. Now, thy sweet spirit speaks

meta.author: O'Reilly, Dowell, 1865-1923
meta.title: Australian poems / by D.

blocks.text: III.

Dreaming o’er boyhood’s sparkling sea, a soul Nears manhood’s unknown shore, and wakes to find Its golden sands beneath his feet. Behind Childhood’s small ripples sparkle, but before, Wild mountains piled, where shadow plays with light. That soul was launched on childhood’s peaceful sea, Beneath the purest beams of parent love, — Bright setting sun —Oh, had the child-soul loved That sacred glory, ere from manhood’s shore, A glance—too late—showed its last rays still linked In a long golden chain, as if to draw

The loved child-spirit in one last embrace, Fading in death. Such light lit childhood’s steps : Now a vast pall of fire and lurid smoke— Soul-burning fire, whose glory fades in smoke, And ashes of chill age—enshrouds the path. Passion the fire—rose-tinted love, its smoke.

“ Purity,” sighs the echo of past thought, Faintly within my memory, “ Be pure.” Were the dead poets pure ? They passed beneath That lurid pall of passion-flame—they died In its wild fire. Their ashes yielded Time,
All his bright hordes of golden poetry, Did they sing purity ? They sang of love, Of woman’s love, that sparkles from her eye ;

meta.author: O'Reilly, Dowell, 1865-1923
meta.title: Australian poems / by D.

blocks.text: Don Juan.

From present life, to live in memory (A waste, where all past deeds imprisoned stray, Till lost in its deep shade—forgetfulness.) But manhood’s morning casts a shadow vague And terrible, trembling in passion-light, Living in passion-light. That shadow wild Can ne’er in beauty smile, as childhood’s smiled.

Lo ! flashing through the lurid morn, the sun In glory rises. Glorious sun ! thy face Loved evermore shall be for thy bright words, “ Heed not the passion glare of manhood’s dawn, Nor think its murky vapours sunlight. See ! How lurid passion mists dissolve before
The strength of pure-souled manhood’s glory. See ! Now the true shadow falls from rising sun. Now is its edge bright golden. May it die
Manhood’s sun set in rays of purity.”
Dark stream of Poetry impure, that soaks
Through marshes rank, whence Nature’s soul has fled ; That slowly eddies round the slimy snag,
Where black-winged thought in evil silence broods. In thy dark eye no love for Nature shines, Reflected love, for Nature frowns on thee ;
Bright lovely Nature’s blue eyed purity

meta.author: O'Reilly, Dowell, 1865-1923
meta.title: Australian poems / by D.

blocks.text: V.
Thought Garden.
On wings of sunlight the snowy cloud
Floats through the blue skies, as the albatross proud, Floats over the sea.
And though a dark shadow glides over the earth, None blame the white angel, whose life gave it birth ; Nor the sun in his glory.
On wdngs of beauty, a maiden bright, Flits ’neath the rays of man’s love sun-light, And a shadow falls,
Society virtue points finger of scorn
At the poor wing-sing’d butterfly, trembling, forlorn. —And, man in his glory ?
Thought of still morn, whose tearful eyes Kind-hearted sun arising dries.
Thought of young day, whose joyous voice Calls every flowret to rejoice :
After whose song—thought of mid-day, Of waving grass, and shadow play, Of organ birds, whose song on high Falls in a gentle lullaby.

meta.author: O'Reilly, Dowell, 1865-1923
meta.title: Australian poems / by D.

blocks.text: A Vision of Childhood.
Deep in Australian wilds,
A far-off voice sublime, That rang through every clime, Found echo weird, and mingled with my dreams.
Earth ! Earth ! give up the dead. Give up the dead, O, sea ;
That for a time, with thee
Were left to slumber, till the Judgment Day.
Awake those slumberers,
Throughout thy trackless deep, That they no longer sleep In awful solitude, the sleep of death.
Hear thy Creator’s voice, Yield up thy treasures vast, On which throughout the past,
Thy coverlet of seaweed has been thrown.
Startled I woke.
Nature’s face ne’er before Smiled with such brilliancy On prostrate devotee,
Who paid his humble tribute at her shrine.

meta.author: O'Reilly, Dowell, 1865-1923
meta.title: Australian poems / by D.

blocks.text: And as its sobbing notes Sank in a wild refrain To rest, an answering strain,
Broke in celestial harmony from heaven.
O that my soul with thine
Could blend ; then we might still In silence listen till
The angelic choirs have ceased their heavenly chime.
He comes ! He comes ! enthroned In majesty. This flickering light That faintly lit Creation’s night,
Would but o’er-cloud her Maker’s radiancy.
Before that dawn divine, That brightens in the sky, Proclaiming judgment nigh,
It fades—as the star fades before the sun.
Sydney, 1881.

meta.author: O'Reilly, Dowell, 1865-1923
meta.title: Australian poems / by D.

blocks.text: VI.
To a Friend.
Echo from song of him who lives for life,
And living, scorns the “morbid” thought of death ; From me returning, whisper to his heart.

The thought of death is soul of manhood’s life ; Life without death were death eternally, For life is night-shade, death the trembling dawn, Through which night-life must pass to spirit-day. Man-soul that sings the soul’s eternity,
Weigh manhood’s life with immortality. Who would return to dreamland’s phantasies
From morn that banished them ? —or childhood’s dream From manhood roused ? The soul awaked from earth

By death’s weird light—eternity’s first ray Ne'er would return to dream again life’s dream ; —That now we dream. Is not that dream more bright, Whose shadow thoughts mingle with morning’s light ? Why curtain slumbering life from the faint rays Of spirit-day, that through death’s window gleam ? Let the thought-rays, born of eternity,
Through death’s uncurtained window shine. Their light Will gently rouse the soul to dazzling life.
True friendship’s lovely form shines best displayed In simple garb of truthful words, undecked Save with the girdle of pure love. Her brow,

meta.author: O'Reilly, Dowell, 1865-1923
meta.title: Australian poems / by D.

blocks.text: To Tennyson.

In fading ranks from manhood’s straining eye. Mingled they move, for time-past’s veil alike Shrouds smile of joy and sorrows ghastly stare. Thus from dim life-light pass Time’s progeny, Born of their father Fate, her fruitful womb Peoples life-world with joys and shades that die, (Fast fading blood-drops fallen from dying life) Ami pass to memory’s dim catacomb, Life-world still moving through life-universe. Life-universe ! Black spot on faint earth-light That dimly threads its path through myriad stars. Earth ! Faintest ray of light from Nature-sun. And Nature-sun ! Weird ignis-fatuus
Of the dark marshes of eternity
Bounded—Oh God, that man should know himself !

Proud thought-waves, what vast rock-bound bars and doors Stay your impetuous course, and break your crests ? Roll back, and sweep the soul o’er your wild sea, Nor strive to wear the bounds of dark eternity.
Fate placed the laurel wreath upon thy brow, The poet’s wand within thy hand, to wave Through thought world, charming its bright fairy forms To deck themselves in words and live with men.

meta.author: O'Reilly, Dowell, 1865-1923
meta.title: Australian poems / by D.

blocks.text: To—In Memory of 15th March, 1884.
Fit cradle for the pure and grand, Maiden, why sing of a “ better land ” ?
The words are but a stepping stone, For thy pure soul, towards the throne Of Nature’s God of love.
And there your music prayer— That God —of love, would spare
Your loved one —moved Love’s heart with its soft tone.
Maiden, when in that “ better land, You purified, together stand,
And sing with all the “ happy band,” The songs of those from sin set free. What though my darkened soul belong Not to thy heaven ! thy bright song Will lift me nearer thee.
Then, from amidst that glorious throng, That chant eternally their triumph song, Spirit, smile down on me.
Bright face, from whose clear eye, The lovely rays of woman purity Fell lighting a dark heart anew. A heart—whose gloomy past,
Clouded by doubt in woman’s faith—at last Lives brightened by the rays that fell from you.

meta.author: Simmonds, James
meta.title: Lyrics : a collection of songs, ballads, and poems

blocks.text: THE WANDERER’S LAMENT.
I.
II.
“ Oh ! where is my home,” desponding I cry, As I rove from the east to the west;
“ Oh! where is that one when sorrow is nigh I may clasp as a friend to my breast.
The homes of content and bright halls of mirth, Like a ruin illumed do I roam,
For ne’er can I find that dear spot of earth, The wanderer may claim as his home.”
“Oil! where is my home where sweet children play, When their dear little tasks are all done,
And the mother is sighing that I am away, Oh ! alas my poor heart, I have none.
Ah ! no I may rove till my hair hath turn’d grey, Still homeless the wanderer must be ;
I have but this hope, when my life’s passed away, 1 hat in heaven there’s a home still for me.' 1

meta.author: Simmonds, James
meta.title: Lyrics : a collection of songs, ballads, and poems

blocks.text: YES OR NO !
I.
II.
Yes or No! Yes or No !
Oli! what mystic spells are these.
Oh ! what trembling
And dissembling
When these words fall on the breeze.
Thrones are shaking, Monarchs quaking,
Patriots they gape for breath ;
Friends are parted
Broken hearted
By these words of Life and Death,
See yon beggar all in tatters, With scarce a rag upon his back,
Ask him kindly ’bout his matters, Why his fortune’s gone to rack ?
He will say a friend deceived him, That’s the cause of all his woe ;
Of every penny he relieved him By saying Yes instead of No !

meta.author: Simmonds, James
meta.title: Lyrics : a collection of songs, ballads, and poems

blocks.text: III.
IV.
Yes or No ! Yes or No !
Upon these words love’s fond hopes turn ; Oh ! what sobbing, And heart throbbing
When the fatal word we learn. Hearts are breaking, Hopes forsaking,
Streams of love they cease to flow ; Oh! what sorrow, On the morrow,
Springs from saying Yes or No !
See yon damsel broken hearted ; Why so cheerless and forlorn ?
Wherefore sadnesss chasing gladness ? Why this night that should be morn ?
Ask her —she will answer kindly— What’s the cause of all her woe ?
And with a tear, she’ll whisper near, ’Twas saying Yes, instead of No !
